eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor

Class NewMacroInvocationPreprocessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewMacroInvocationPreprocessor

  • public class NewMacroInvocationPreprocessor
extends java.lang.Object
    Special preprocessor that handles expansion of one (top-level) macro invocation. Top level means that the expanded token with the macro name is part of the currently processed source code file (main C file or source code in a header file).

    During the expansion of the top-level macro, nested macro expansions may happen.

    The macro-expansion process is specified in the C specification (linked in our wiki). Comments such as [cpp.subst] in this class refer to subsections of that specification document.

      • expandMacrosInTokenList

        public Pair<java.util.List<IToken>,java.lang.Integer> expandMacrosInTokenList(java.util.List<IToken> tokens,
                                                                              java.util.List<IToken> successorTokens,
                                                                              eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewCPreprocessor.FilePreprocessorContext context,
                                                                              eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewMacroInvocationPreprocessor.TokenDisablingContext tokenDisablingContext,
                                                                              NewCPreprocessor.PreprocessorUsageInformation preprocessorUsageInformation,
                                                                              eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewCPreprocessor.IncludedFilesContext includedFiles)
                                                                       throws eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewCPreprocessor.PreprocessorException
        This scans the given token list once and expands macro invocations.

        This is not the normal "preprocess tokens" method. It does only macro expansion (e.g., no include-directive handling). It also returns just a token list instead of a PreprocessorTokenReplacement.

        This is used as sub-step to

        1. expand macro-argument tokens,
        2. run a "rescan" during expansion of a macro (After parameters have been inserted and stringification and concatenation has been done, the resulting token list must be scanned once more and newly emerged macro calls must be expanded too [cpp.rescan].),
        3. expand the tokens in an #include directive.

        This is a central part of the macro expansion algorithm. The definition of this process is difficult and has a lot of corner cases. The description in the specification is bad, but the original pseudocode algorithm helps understand it. One particular difficult part is the successorTokens parameter. The tokens that should be expanded (e.g., the tokens resulting from the parameter insertion and concatenation steps in a macro expansion) must be given in the tokens parameter. If this method finds that the last token in the tokens parameter is the name of a function macro and successor tokens starts with a parameter list, then this function-macro call must be expanded too. In this special macro-expansion, the currently expanded macro, if any, must not be disabled any more. successorTokens is Collections.emptyList() when expanding a macro argument or tokens in an include directive. successorTokens is set to "all remaining tokens of the current context" during a rescan.

        Throws:
        eu.cqse.check.framework.preprocessor.c.new_c_preprocessor.NewCPreprocessor.PreprocessorException
